Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Probability Theory and Combinatorial Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is to support a conference on Probability Theory and Combinatorial Optimization that will take place at Duke University on March 14-15, 2015. The conference covers topics such as random structures and algorithms, random graphs and networks, probabilistic combinatorial optimization, and concentration inequalities.

The conference brings together a diverse set of speakers and participants in probability theory and combinatorial optimization, and it is devoted to discuss how to make progress on some of the most important questions in the field. The conference tentatively features eleven talks delivered by exceptional scholars alongside with a number of short presentations delivered by graduate students, postdocs, and other young researchers. The conference seeks to facilitate the interaction between the new generations of mathematicians and the key figures of the field. The conference organizers are committed to trying to help advance the careers of graduate students, postdocs, women, minorities and other young researchers in the field. Priority for financial support will be given to several members of such groups.

More information is available on the conference website at http://sites.duke.edu/steele2015/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funds from this grant supported the Duke Conference on Probability Theory and Combinatorial Optimization which took place on Duke’s campus on March 14-15, 2015. The conference covered topics such as random structures and algorithms, random graphs and networks, probabilistic combinatorial optimization, and concentration inequalities.

The conference brought together more than 100 registered participants. The funds from the National Science Foundation partially supported 25 participants, of whom 68% are young researchers and 24% are women. The Fuqua School of Business at Duke University and the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania joined the National Science Foundation to partially fund the conference. The Institute of Mathematical Statistics provided co-sponsorship. The conference was the result of the fruitful collaboration of different faculty members at Duke University, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Connecticut, and Princeton University.

The conference featured ten invited talks delivered by scientific leader in the field. Specifically, David Aldous, Sourav Chatterjee, James A. Fill, David Gamarnik, Gábor Lugosi, Sasha Rakhlin, Sneha Subramanian, Ruth J. Williams, Joseph E. Yukich, and J. Michael Steele each delivered a 40-minute plenary talk. Young researchers had the opportunity to present their current research in a dedicated plenary session. By bringing together a diverse set of speakers and participants, the conference fostered the interaction and exchange of ideas between the key figures in the field and a new generation of young researchers. (Conference information can be found at http://sites.duke.edu/steele2015/.)

Broader Impacts. The conference was an exciting opportunity for junior and senior researchers to be exposed to the state-of-the-art ideas in probability theory and combinatorial optimization. The conference was a unique addition that strengthened and complemented the calendar of regional and national meetings in probability theory for spring of 2015. The conference schedule and the talks delivered by the young researchers facilitated the interaction among participants which helped develop new fruitful research collaborations.
